title.narrative: Strengthening Civil Society Engagement for Family Planning in Francophone West Africa

description.narrative:
The Strengthening Civil Society Engagement for Family Planning in Francophone West Africa project supports the establishment of a more solid partnership between government and civil society in Benin, Mali, Senegal, Niger, and Burkina Faso to promote family planning (FP) and to assist governments to be accountable for their commitments to FP programming and policies. The initiative builds on agreements made by eight French-speaking West African countries at a 2011 meeting in Ouagadougou on family planning in the context of population and development (Ouagadougou Partnership). The agreements included a commitment to reduce maternal mortality and unmet need for family planning in the region by 25% by 2015. Project activities focus on creating and mobilizing a coalition of civil society organizations committed to FP in each country to actively participate in the guidance, coordination, and management of FP endeavors at the national level.
Specific objectives include: 1. Strengthening civil society coalitions in Benin, Mali, Senegal, Niger, and Burkina Faso in advocacy and political dialogue for resource mobilization and government accountability for the implementation of national FP costed implementation plans (CIPs) 2. Ensuring youth are actively involved in repositioning FP in their countries as Youth Ambassadors (YAs) and coalition members.

The project, initiated in 2011, has been extended for two years, expanding activities to two new countries (Niger and Burkina Faso) beyond the original three (Benin, Mali, and Senegal).
Key activities include: 1. Reinforcing the capacity of civil society coalitions across all five countries to advocate to governments for family planning and contribute to the international dialogue surrounding it 2. Tapping into the growing use of social media in West Africa to build the capacity of FP coalitions and champions, including youth and women’s groups, to use Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube to engage civil society in promoting FP in each country and among the countries 3. Engaging youth as coalition members and partners, thereby ensuring advocacy efforts are representative of those who use family planning services and fostering the next generation of advocates 4. Supporting continued implementation of and public reporting on the Ouagadougou meeting commitments as well as general strengthening of mechanisms for transparency and accountability in family planning programs and policies.
